paper.title: Information systems management and strategy formulation: the ‘stages of growth’ model revisited

paper.abstract: Abstract. The original ‘stages of growth’ model, as applied to the field of Information Systems (Gibson u0026 Nolan, 1974), may be viewed as seminal, given the influence it has had on both theory and practice (Nolan, 1984; Sullivan, 1985; Ward, et al., 1990). This is so, despite the modelu0027s lack of substantiation based on empirical evidence, the overly simplistic assumptions on which it is based, and the limited focus of the original concept (Benbasat, et al., 1984; King u0026 Kraemer, :[80],"its first appearance, the model has been refined following many applications (Nolan, 1979, 1984). In addition, others have developed ‘stages of growth’ models of their own. For example, Somogyi u0026 Galliers, (1987a, b)provide a model depicting the move from basic data processing systems to strategic information systems, tracing the early days of commercial applications of computing through to the present day (Ward et al. 1990). Earl (1983, 1986, 1988, 1989) proposes a stages-model for information systems planning, as does Bhabuta (1988), while Hirschheim, et al.
